author: pipermerriam
content: Alright, I should have bootnodes for people to experiment with early next week.  My v5.1 implementation is now runable from the command line and should be a minimally viable client for the network (in the branch I'm currently working on).

author: pipermerriam
content: <@!194432762315407360> where can I read up on the latest for topic discovery?

author: .fjl
content: the latest status of the research is still in https://github.com/ethereum/devp2p/issues/136

author: .fjl
content: I'm working with the people who commented last there to try out their solution idea (the distance-based topic distribution)

author: .fjl
content: we're going to have the next call soon, I can invite you if you want

author: .fjl
content: I've also been investigating this paper: https://ieeexplore.ieee.org/document/8647195

author: .fjl
content: It's not freely available unfortunately, you will have to acquire it from sci hub or something

author: .fjl
content: The paper is very nice, but I'm not sure if the idea there would work for us because it's based on Chord DHT and doesn't seem to be concerned with security at all

author: .fjl
content: The main idea in there (for me) was the concept of a KOPSON (key-order preserving structured overlay network)

author: .fjl
content: they use this KOPSON construction to create an overlay network where all nodes are organized in 'key order', the key being the provided service

author: .fjl
content: the KOPSON allows for 'range queries', so you can just find the first node providing the thing you want and then walk from there

author: .fjl
content: what I'm unclear about is how they would be able to handle any attacks where someone just places a bunch of malicious nodes in the DHT

author: .fjl
content: would definitely recommend looking into the paper though, if only for the citations

author: .fjl
content: the authors even say they're the first to investigate DHTs for service discovery, and I can confirm that because I've been searching for papers around this topic for years and could never find anything

author: pipermerriam
content: K, I've got some reading to do before I think I can effectively ask questions.
